conclusion: Objects A and B are released above two cloth-covered platforms.
Gravity produces a downward acceleration on each object.
Object A is positioned above the left platform supported by blocks C (blue, shorter) and D (purple, taller).
Object B is positioned above the right platform supported by blocks E (dark, shorter) and F (red, taller).
Objects A and B descend toward their respective platforms due to gravity.
The cloth sags until it meets the tallest block in each group.
Object A touches the upper face of block D first, while object B touches the upper face of block F first.
At the instant of contact, the upward normal force supplied by the touched blocks grows until it equals the weight of the falling objects.
The downward acceleration of objects A and B is brought to zero; any small bounce is quickly damped by friction and the cloth.
Object A ends up resting mainly on block D, possibly lightly on block C if the cloth is slack.
Object B ends up resting mainly on block F, possibly lightly on block E if the cloth is slack.
All motion stops as gravity is balanced by the normal forces of the blocks, resulting in a static system.
Objects A and B fall until the cloth lets them touch the tallest blocks beneath (D on the left, F on the right). After deceleration, they come to rest on those blocks; nothing else occurs.
